title: Can 'nagareru' or 'utsukushi' be used as names in Japanese? - Quora

response.answer_text: While there are many instances of words used as names in English (Hope, Faith, etc.) and Japanese (Hikaru 光/to shine, Megumi 恵/blessing, etc.) alike, usually 4+ syllable words like nagareru or utsukushii are not considered for names. The reason is that verbs and adjectives have okurigana attached to them to complete the word’s meaning, kind of like how the “st” in “1st” lets you know that it’s “first” not “onest.” In 流れる, the kanji is “naga” and tells you the meaning “to flow.” The “reru” in hiragana completes the actual word for “to flow.” In 美しい, “utsuku” is the kanji reading and alerts you to the meaning “beautiful”, and “shii” in hiragana completes the actual word for “beautiful.” That said, there are instances of verbs and adjectives as names. Obviously, they’re written without the hiragana at the end. Examples are Mamoru 守 (to protect, written 守る as a regular word), Shizuka 静 (quiet, written 静か as a regular word), and Hikaru 光 (to shine, written 光る as a regular word). This is possible because the okurigana is only one character. However, there are plenty of names that use the kanji for “flow” 流, where it’s read as ryuu, ru, or nagaru. For example, 纏流子 (Ryuko Matoi), or Haruhi Suzumiya creator 谷川流 (Nagaru Tanigawa). The kanji is used alone as Tanigawa’s first name, but it’s a special reading reserved for names. The kanji for “beautiful” 美 is also very common in names, especially female names. It’s most commonly read as “mi” and can appear at the beginning, middle or end of a name. Examples are 美智子 (Michiko), 留美子 (Rumiko), 恵美 (Emi). Fun fact: Michiko is the name of the retired empress, Rumiko is the name of the creator of Inuyasha, and Emi makes use of an alternate reading to the Megumi kanji I showed you at the top. You could even be creative and read 恵美 as Megumi! The actual word “blessing” is written 恵み. In short, I hope this answers your question. If you have other questions, let me know.

The whole word “Nagareru” or “Utsukushi”, I have never heard any name like that and I am pretty sure that it would sound little bit odd to Japanese people. Instead, you can partially use Kanji of the word 流れる(Nagareru) / 美しい (Utsukushi) and make it different. For example.. 春流(Haru / 春-Spring 流-Current) 美流(Miryu/ 美-beauty 流-Current) 美鈴(Misuzu/ 美-beauty 鈴-bell) You can make so many combination with kanjis, I hope it helps :)
It wouldn’t sound like a name. I wouldn’t use them as names as I wouldn’t name someone “flow/stream/flush/pour” or “beautiful” in English.
